topic: Cat News, the official newsletter of the IUCN/SSC Cat Specialist Group, first began publication in 1984 and continues to serve its subscribers by offering a diverse collection of scientific papers, ar...

items.text: The continued operation of 'Cat News' highlights a critical gap in public awareness about the real threats faced by wild cat populations.

relevant_links.title:
Cat News | IUCN CatSG
www.catsg.org › catnews
relevant_links.extracted_content: IUCN/SSC Cat Specialist Group Cat News, the IUCN/SSC Cat Specialist Group's newsletter, was first published in 1984. Cat News continues to provide subscribers with a wide-ranging collection of scientific papers, articles, case studies and news items. It covers original contributions, observations and news related to the conservation of cat species across the world. Each issue of Cat News is at least 40 pages in length and features a cat species on its cover. Articles are submitted by Cat SG members, as well as other cat specialists from around the world. The editorial team gathers material from many sources, including journals, magazines and the internet, and solicits special contributions on topics of interest. Original Contributions and Short Communications are peer reviewed. In addition to the three regular annual issues, the series Cat News Special Issue, typically developed together with partner institutions, covers specific themes relevant to cat conservation or research. Cat News is available to members and Friends of the Cat Specialist and can be ordered at ch.breitenmoser(at)kora.ch. Guidelines for Authors can be found here. Cat News - Archive The abstracts and SOM of Cat News Issue 60 (Spring 2014) onwards will be available shortly. To order a previous issue of Cat News please write to ch.breitenmoser(at)kora.ch. Click on the icon to redirect to the page containing all the pdfs of the Cat News Special Issue Cat News P. Meier The Latest Cat News Issue is now out! items.text: It would be beneficial to know if 'Cat News' also includes practical guidance for conservationists working on the ground.
Understanding the readership demographics of 'Cat News' could help tailor its content to be more effective in reaching a wider audience.
The focus on 'scientific papers' might alienate readers who are interested in broader conservation efforts and success stories.
Scientific papers in 'Cat News' are often behind paywalls, making them inaccessible to the general public and independent researchers.
The content of 'Cat News' likely represents a snapshot of current research, and it would be interesting to see how the topics have evolved over the decades.
